Xavi Simons
After years of growing up quickly off the pitch, Xavi Simons is now doing the same on it.
A child prodigy and teenage internet sensation (you won’t regret spending five minutes of your time watching the little No 8 with blond curls playing for Barcelona Under-13s in the Republic of Ireland in 2016) has matured into one of Europe’s most exciting wide attackers.
It is less about the Instagram followers these days (approaching six million, in case you were wondering) and more about the numbers that really matter. A total of 31 goals and 27 assists for PSV Eindhoven and RB Leipzig across the last two seasons tell a story.
He was a creative force in the Bundesliga in 2023-24 and the numbers support this. Looking at Simons’ expected assists — which denote the expected goals value of the shot that is assisted — his rate of 0.33 per 90 minutes in the Bundesliga last season was only bettered by five players across the division.
Simons was born to play the game. Regillo, his father, was a professional footballer in the top flight in the Netherlands for the best part of a decade and named his youngest son after Xavi Hernandez, the Barcelona legend (Faustino, Xavi’s older brother, who shares the same birthday as him, was named after the Colombia striker Faustino Asprilla).
Raised in Spain, after his family relocated to Alicante when his father’s playing career finished, Simons signed for Barcelona aged seven and was catapulted into the spotlight, appearing in Nike commercials alongside Neymar and Ronaldinho as a kid.
His career has been nomadic. At 21, he has already played in Ligue 1, the Eredivisie and the Bundesliga, left Barcelona, signed for Paris Saint-Germain, and rejoined the French club 12 months later after moving to PSV for a season. Are you keeping up? Most of his opponents aren’t.
A quick and dynamic runner with a sharp football brain and exceptional technique, Simons can score goals of every description and play any attacking role. He glides past defenders and is a centre-forward’s dream because of his ability to spot a through ball. As for the outside of his right foot, it’s a thing of beauty.
On top of all that, Simons has the fortitude to thrive at the highest level. “His mentality, his mindset – it’s unprecedented,” said Ruud van Nistelrooy, the former Manchester United and Real Madrid striker and his former coach at PSV Eindhoven.
All perfect, then? Not quite. Simons has not yet recaptured his club form in a Netherlands shirt. Note the word ‘yet’. Like most things with Simons, it’s when, not if, everything falls into place.

Johan Bakayoko
Johan Bakayoko is following a well-trodden path at PSV Eindhoven: young wingers who earn their stripes on their way to Europe’s major leagues. For a team that prides itself on attacking displays and passing football, there is an understanding at the club that wingers become the match-winners.
Bakayoko is expected to fetch a fee higher than Hirving Lozano, Noni Madueke, Memphis Depay, Steven Bergwijn, Donyell Malen or Arjen Robben — all were signed by PSV as youngsters, or developed through their academy, and rank among their top 10 sales.
A left-footed right-winger in a 4-3-3, Bakayoko does more than cut inside and shoot. Often he is double-marked and delivers back-post crosses, perfect for the PSV No 9 Luuk De Jong. He is just as prepared to dribble on the outside and produce cutbacks. His return of 13 goals and 10 assists in all competitions last season is evidence of that — De Jong was the only other PSV player with double digits in both.
While many of his ’shot-creating actions’ — the two attacking actions that lead to a shot — come from those crosses and passes, a healthy smattering are from his aggressive dribbling, as shown below.
Bakayoko has just completed his second senior season, helping PSV win the Eredivisie for the first time since 2016. They poached him as a 16-year-old from Anderlecht and he spent two seasons with Jong PSV (their under-21s), playing against senior teams in the second-tier Eerste Divisie. That progress went hand-in-hand with his age group performances for Belgium — his father is Ivorian and his mother Rwandan, but Bakayoko opted to play for his country of birth.
He only made his senior international debut in September and has played 12 times, part of the emerging generation of Belgian talent.
Those who have watched Jeremy Doku’s move to Manchester City might put Bakayoko in the same category: a player with outstanding technique, speed and agility, but an inconsistent end product. Bakayoko, though, is closer in style to Eden Hazard and Leandro Trossard — an all-round winger who can go both ways, a passer as much as a dribbler or finisher, able to escape pressure and take contact. He has that confidence, too, and told The Athletic how he plans to be in the conversation for the Ballon d’Or in the next five years.
Bakayoko had the most progressive carries into the final third in the Eredivisie last season (101) and of the 15 players to attempt 100-plus dribbles in the league, his completion rate was the third-highest (53.2 per cent). He can be patchy and on a bad day is a moments player, but his inventiveness and capacity to play off the cuff warrants a place at a major tournament.

Jeremy Doku
“For my team-mates, you can see that they are used to winning titles,” Jeremy Doku said after lifting the Premier League trophy in his debut season at Manchester City.
“They know how to handle these moments. Now I’m here for the first time, I’ve also got that mentality and when I go back to the national team, they will also see that I’ve changed.”
As Domenico Tedesco’s vibrant Belgium squad look to step out of the shadow of the previous ‘golden generation’, Doku could not have asked for a better environment to establish a winning mindset before a major tournament.
It has been a chaotic campaign for Doku since signing from Rennes last summer. After initially struggling to get up to speed, the 22-year-old ousted Jack Grealish to earn a spot on the left wing, before being restricted to the role of impactful substitute for the latter stages of the season.
Chaos is a word that often rolls off the tongue when discussing Doku. He is a throwback, a winger who loves to hug the touchline and face up his man before dribbling past them with a body feint or drop of the shoulder.
Opposition full-backs must be sick of the relentless unpredictability of Doku’s running when he has the ball. To highlight just how prolific he is, Doku’s 9.5 attempted take-ons per 90 minutes and 8.3 carries into the penalty area per 90 minutes are the highest rates of any player across Europe’s top five leagues — and by some distance.
“This guy… really, you don’t know what he is going to do,” Guardiola said of Doku this season and in some ways, that is a key area for him to improve.
For all of the flair, pace and trickery, the fact you cannot predict what Doku is going to do is part of why his end product can be lacking at the crucial moment. A return of three goals and eight assists from 29 games is fine for a first season in the Premier League, but his manager and those around him will expect him to improve on those numbers next campaign.
Despite this summer’s tournament being his second European Championship with Belgium, it is easy to forget that Doku only turned 22 in May and has so much attacking elegance to refine.
Nevertheless, this summer’s Jeremy Doku arrives as a Premier League winner.

Kevin De Bruyne
So, what can we expect from Kevin De Bruyne at Euro 2024?
Well, he might not actually be as dominant as previously, but he can be equally as dangerous.
He ended the season with a remarkable six goals and 17 assists for Manchester City — the remarkable thing being that he only started his season in January after surgery on a serious hamstring injury.
There were questions about whether he would be used in a deeper role upon his return, an effort to save his legs as the 32-year-old gets towards the end of his career, but he operated high up the pitch, with City cramming as many players into the middle as possible, providing plenty of cover and support if the ball was lost.
At the end of the season, he said he had been playing higher than usual since his return. “I try to find space and (get) in pockets and give myself a little fraction of time so I can help my team-mates score as much as possible.”
Despite his higher position, it is interesting to see the evolution in the locations of his chances created over time (below). This season, when City have needed him to create from deep, those enticing, punchy forward passes are still firmly in his locker.
Without the ball, he is still asked to lead City’s press alongside Erling Haaland in a 4-4-2 and he still has the energy levels for that and plenty of other running besides.
He is still having a big impact on matches in terms of goal contributions, but there was a period in the spring as he battled on through some minor injury concerns that must have impacted his performances in certain big matches in particular, including against Chelsea, Manchester United, Liverpool and Arsenal.
On those occasions, it seemed like nothing came off: never mind those passes nobody else can see, he was barely able to combine with any of his team-mates.
It might seem churlish to discuss performances like that when he clearly made such a huge contribution to City’s season regardless, but it is worth bearing in mind given Belgium cannot call on the number of top-level performers as they could in previous tournaments, and there might be more emphasis on De Bruyne to make the difference.
He has continued to show that if there is any space behind a defence to play into, he will play into it — something any team will have to be wary of this summer. If defenders are sucked away from their stations and towards the twinkle toes of Jeremy Doku on the wing, then shifting the ball to De Bruyne would be a good bet to take advantage.
De Bruyne can still be expected to make a difference in what could well be his final major tournament for his country.

Lois Openda
Lois Openda wasn’t always this prolific.
After spending his early days on the wing, it took a two-season loan from Club Bruges to Vitesse Arnhem and a shift inside to help unlock his true potential.
Openda scored just five times in 53 appearances for Club Bruges but netted 37 goals in 88 competitive appearances in the Netherlands, piquing the interest of clubs across Europe. Everton initially pushed hard for his signature, but the Liege native eventually joined Lens instead.
Two years on, Openda heads to this summer’s European Championship as one of the continent’s most in-form strikers.
A direct, dynamic forward capable of penalty-box poaching and penetrative dribbling, the 24-year-old thrived with RB Leipzig in the Bundesliga this season after a club-record €43million (£36.6m; $46.8m) move last summer.
Alongside an impressive haul of 24 goals and seven assists in the league, he also scored four times in eight Champions League matches, including a double at the Etihad against Manchester City in November.
Openda’s movement is smart, particularly in the box. A clinical finisher, he managed 22 non-penalty league goals for Leipzig from an expected goals figure of 19.7, performing above expectation. Only one of those strikes came from outside the area, but there is more to his game than poaching.
The Belgian is not an incessant dribbler but is highly effective when he does run with the ball. Only five players created more chances from carries in the Bundesliga this season, with Openda notably ahead of Bayern Munich pair Kingsley Coman and Jamal Musiala.
It seems only a matter of time before even bigger clubs come calling. Openda is attracted by the prospect of playing in England, with Manchester United and Tottenham Hotspur linked with a move for his services this season.
But the immediate task is forcing his way into a stacked Belgium front line. Openda has made just two starts for his national team and head coach Domenico Tedesco is also able to call upon the considerable talents of Romelu Lukaku, Leandro Trossard, Jeremy Doku and the gifted 21-year-old Johan Bakayoko.
After the season he has had, though, don’t bet against Openda adding to his tally this summer.

Radu Dragusin
It’s funny how football works. Eric Dier has unexpectedly gone deep in the Champions League this season playing for Bayern Munich. That could have been Radu Dragusin. The Romanian turned down Bayern to join Tottenham Hotspur for £26million ($33m) over the winter, creating the opportunity for Dier to reunite with Harry Kane in Germany.
Opportunities for Dragusin at Tottenham, on the other hand, have been few and far between. He left a team that played a back three (Genoa) for one deploying a back four and joined as first-choice defenders Cristian Romero and Micky van de Ven returned from injury.
Dragusin has needed to learn patience, having clocked up just 429 Premier League minutes since moving to north London (below).
Still 22, Dragusin is raw and has a lot of room to improve, but he is a big personality and sets standards on the training ground. Giorgio Chiellini took him under his wing when he moved to Juventus as a teenager. The legendary Italian defender, who captained the Azzurri side that won the last Euros, saw his younger self in Dragusin and liked his mentality.
“I’d like to be a mix of Leonardo Bonucci and Matthijs de Ligt,” Dragusin said while at Juventus. “But Chiellini is my idol.” Dragusin played every game of Genoa’s promotion campaign and his coach, Alberto Gilardino, a former striker who knows a good defender when he sees one, was reluctant to lose him halfway through the club’s first season back in Serie A.
Dragusin’s mindset comes, in part, from being brought up by a family of Olympians. His father represented Romania in volleyball and his mother was on the basketball team. But instead of Paris, Dragusin will be in Germany this summer. He has what it takes to captain his country in the future and won’t lack offers if his pathway at Tottenham remains blocked. Atalanta competed for his signature in January and he continues to be held in high esteem in Italy.

David Hancko
To watch Feyenoord is to watch David Hancko. Arne Slot earned the Liverpool job after transforming the Rotterdam club into one of the most stylish teams in Europe and the Slovakian centre-back was key to their build-up play.
Hancko’s biggest strength is his variety. No player completed more passes in the Dutch Eredivisie last season (2,671), nearly 10 per cent more than the second-most. He also made the most progressive carries among centre-backs in the entire division, frequently the beneficiary of a rapid interchange to advance to halfway before he was trusted to play the line-breaking pass.
That is reflected in his smarterscout profile — which gives players a series of ratings from zero to 99 — where his carry and dribble volume (92 out of 99) is crucial to advancing his team up the field and getting the ball into dangerous areas (xG from ball progression, 91 out of 99).
Some of this is due to Feyenoord’s status as one of the Netherlands’ most ball-dominant sides, but it also speaks to his natural attacking instincts, developed as a wing-back in the youth academy of MSK Zilina. His hometown, Prievidza, was a centre for the Czechoslovakian resistance in the Second World War and also the home of former Liverpool defender Martin Skrtel, the team he grew up supporting.
“It all started with the Istanbul Champions League final in 2005, which my parents allowed me to watch until the end and I didn’t have to go to bed even when extra time was going on,” he said. “And then came Skrtel.”
Hancko has spoken openly about his desire to one day feature in the Premier League and his quality in possession means that is a realistic proposition. However, he had to overcome a difficult period early in his career, as a major move to Fiorentina as a 21-year-old went disastrously wrong after he was benched by coach Stefano Pioli and was then sent out on loan after just six months.
However, former Arsenal midfielder Tomas Rosicky, working as sporting director at Sparta Prague, suggested that Hancko move to centre-back — and he rebuilt his reputation in the Czech capital.
There, he met and married former Czech tennis star Kristyna Pliskova, before being signed permanently by Feyenoord for €6million (£5.1m; $6.5m) in 2022.
“I found it completely bizarre that in De Kuip people cheer as loudly for a good tackle as for an offensive action,” he said soon after signing. “I’m still not used to that.”
For Slovakia, coach Francesco Calzona will often play him as a left-back in a 4-3-3, where he has a good relationship with veteran winger Robert Mak, while 18-year-old prodigy Leo Sauer, one of his Feyenoord team-mates, may also be given game time.

Artem Dovbyk
The very last touch of Artem Dovbyk’s debut campaign was the most surreal of them all.
Nearly all of his penalty kicks are arrowed to the goalkeeper’s left, but that doesn’t make them any more stoppable — his last of the season made it 7-0 to Girona on the night, sealed his hat-trick, and meant he became the first player in 16 years to win La Liga’s golden boot playing for a team other than Barcelona, Real Madrid and Atletico Madrid.
This isn’t just a purple patch, either. Dovbyk arrived off the back of a 24-goal season in his home country — shirt tucked in, right arm bandaged, buzzcut untouched — to hammer home 24 more in Spain. Flinging himself at crosses, slamming the ball into the bottom corners, or just applying the finishing touch, it quickly became clear that Girona had found a natural-born goalscorer to convert chances into points.
Forming a particularly potent partnership with Savio on the left, Dovbyk does his best work in the box and is particularly good when he can attack the space on the transition. Almost 94 per cent of his shots came from within the box last season — all but one of his goals — while no player in Europe’s ’big five’ leagues, not even Erling Haaland, took a greater proportion of their touches in the opposing penalty area.
Despite his obvious raw power, Dovbyk is neat and tidy when he needs to be, bringing his talented team-mates into play around the penalty area. Away at Rayo Vallecano in November, there was an almost comical scene in which he backed up and up and up into the penalty area, standing with his foot on the ball, his back to goal, with defenders climbing on his back, before casually rolling a lay-off for Miguel Gutierrez to shoot.
That was moments after he had a delicate backheel cleared off the line and minutes before he left Abdul Mumin sprawled on the ground with devastating movement and then blasted home the equaliser. He does the delicate things as well as the destructive.
Dovbyk will probably not get the same service this summer, even if his prolific club partner Viktor Tsygankov will start off to his right, but his ability to tear through the gears and crash the box means that opposing centre-backs will have their hands full.

Georgiy Sudakov
When Mykhailo Mudryk left Shakhtar Donetsk in January 2023, the Ukrainian side were looking for someone to step into his role and lead the team forward.
They didn’t have to look far as Georgiy Sudakov had already grown into one of the stars of the side. The midfielder is rated as one of the brightest young talents in Ukraine.
Born in Brianka, Sudakov came onto the radar of Metalist Kharkiv while playing for his local club Sokil Brianka. He quickly became one of the most exciting prospects and his progress led to Shakhtar bringing him to the club in 2017.
The 21-year-old has finished his second season of regular first-team football. He is a versatile midfielder who can operate centrally or in a more advanced No 10 role.
Sudakov is a technically gifted, press-resistant footballer and has a passing range and vision that make him a creative threat. That is backed up by his smarterscout profile — which gives players a series of ratings from zero to 99 — which highlights his effectiveness in possession to advance the ball into dangerous areas (xG from ball progression, 78 out of 99).
He is comfortable varying his passing range but can also progress his team up the pitch himself (carry and dribble volume, 71 out of 99) and is not afraid to shoot if the opportunity presents itself (shot volume, 79 out of 99).
Sudakov is not going to be the defensive lynchpin of a team’s midfield, but he can still be effective out of possession. He can read the game well and is effective at recovering possession (ball recoveries and interceptions; 79 out of 99) for his team.
Shakhtar are preparing for his exit and an impressive tournament may push him further towards the exit. CEO Sergei Palkin said recently: “This summer window, he (Sudakov) has a big chance to move to some big clubs. We have had some contacts with big clubs and some are not negotiating with us directly but are getting a feel for the summer environment. He will definitely move to a top European club this summer.”
Sudakov has been linked with most of England’s top clubs. Napoli saw a £34million ($43.3m) bid rejected in January, with the Ukrainian side now setting an asking price of around £60million.
That may increase depending on his tournament impact. It is his chance to shine on the world stage, two years on from hiding in makeshift bomb shelters with his family in the early stages of Russia’s invasion of his country.

Patrik Schick
Picture Patrik Schick. You’re remembering that goal against Scotland in the last European Championship, aren’t you?
A brief recap: Schick was the tournament’s joint-top scorer three years ago with five goals, but lost out to Cristiano Ronaldo in the Golden Boot award because the Portugal captain had registered an assist.
Schick’s crowning moment was his long-range strike against Scotland — where the mind’s eye summons not just the cleanness of the strike, but the image of goalkeeper David Marshall laying askew in his net like a marionette with its strings cut.
There was a touch of David Beckham — Schick owned a dozen of his shirts as a child. Another story from that time — his father, a Prague confectioner, nagged Schick one too many times from the touchline, only to be flipped the middle finger by his son mid-game.
That pugnacity is more emblematic of his style and was shown by the first goal in that Scotland game, a brave header, where he beat two Scottish defenders and still generated enough power to send it inside the far post despite falling away from goal.
Still at Bayer Leverkusen — he has just completed his fourth season at the German champions — the illusion is that nothing has changed from three years ago. That masks the challenges the 6ft 3in (190cm) forward has faced, the most central of these being a groin issue, first suffered in October 2022, which afflicted him for almost 18 months.
“It was eight months in which I saw no progress, no improvement, simply nothing,” he describes. “It was tough and I gradually lost drive.”
He had already faced medical issues earlier in his career. Having completed all the paperwork to join Juventus, even posing in the Italian giants’ kit, a medical flagged inflammation in his heart. He was later given the all-clear.
Xabi Alonso’s Leverkusen are an outstanding team and by the time Schick returned, he had lost his place to Nigeria international Victor Boniface and was facing competition for minutes from versatile attacker Amine Adli.
But Schick made the most of his rotational role, chipping in with several crucial interventions that kept Leverkusen’s 51-game unbeaten run alive. Among his last seven goals, there has been a 92nd-minute equaliser, a 93rd-minute equaliser (and then, in the same game, a 97th-minute winner), and a 91st-minute winner.
As you can see below, he reserves his shots for the most lucrative areas within the width of the goalframe, like any good striker should.
Stylistically, Schick is different from his Leverkusen counterparts — he is more of a poacher, clinical in the air and wise in his movement. He is excellent in his hold-up play and is useful in a club side that floods runners into the box, but his goalscoring will be more of a focal point for the national team.

Khvicha Kvaratskhelia
In the sporting world, Georgia is known for rugby union, wrestling, and judo. Their footballing pedigree, at the elite level, is shallow. But this nation, overshadowed by Russia, their northern neighbour, even since their independence in 1991, will now compete at their first major tournament — and the central reason is Napoli’s Khvicha Kvaratskhelia.
The 23-year-old left-winger broke into cultural consciousness during a spellbinding 2022-23 campaign at Napoli, where 12 goals and 13 assists in the league led Luciano Spalletti’s side to their first Serie A title in 33 years. The city bequeathed him a new nickname, borrowed from their greatest footballing son — ’Kvaradona’. Last season, police in Naples arrested a fugitive from Georgia who risked capture to see his hero play in person.
The 2023-24 season has been less overtly spectacular, with Napoli slumping to 10th in the league after Spalleti’s departure. However, Kvaratskhelia tallied only one fewer goal, despite suffering from a lack of continuity behind him at left-back.
What’s his secret? Watching Kvaratskhelia is different from watching most left-wingers — he is physically larger and stockier, with his dribbling style idiosyncratically upright. But these traits, allied with superb technical ability, force defenders into making late and hasty decisions, and he is then quick, strong and ambidextrous enough to go the other way.
In last season’s Serie A, only AC Milan’s Rafael Leao carried the ball into the penalty area more than Kvaratskhelia, while no player created more shots from take-ons, or was fouled more. He also had the second-most progressive carries across Europe’s top five leagues, trailing only Manchester City’s Jeremy Doku.
This unusual style means his attacking game has variety. Just 51 per cent of his shot-creating actions — denoting the two attacking actions that lead to a shot — come from open-play passes, the third-lowest rate among forwards in Serie A this season.
In this sense, Kvaratskhelia is essentially system-independent. He only needs the ball to feet and then creates his own chances. With international football less tactically developed than its club counterpart, this augurs well for Willy Sagnol’s Georgia.
Internationally, he is used as a nominal striker in a 5-3-2/3-5-2, but typically drops deeper as support for partner Georges Mikautadze. He will likely be the closest player to hold a ‘free role’ as this tournament has.
Kvaratskhelia’s name is Georgian for “burning coal”, but that does not quite feel suitable. This is not a player who slowly smoulders, but one who bursts with pyrotechnics.

Cristiano Ronaldo
Cristiano Ronaldo. One of the greatest forwards to ever play the game.
At 39, he is not the all-conquering attacker he was at his peak, but he is still a goalscoring phenomenon. If the Saudi Pro League was a place for experienced professionals to wind down their careers, then Ronaldo missed the memo.
He has recorded 44 goals and 13 assists in 45 games in all competitions this season for Al Nassr — 35 in the league set a new record and it is the fourth different league he has finished top scorer in.
In total, he has 58 goals in 64 matches since he joined in January 2023 after his contract was terminated by Manchester United.
The explosive interview that led to the mutual parting of ways ended an unsuccessful return to the club he had joined from Sporting Lisbon at the age of 18. Ronaldo scored goals — because that’s what he does — but fans and pundits questioned whether he was helping or hindering the collective.
They were the same questions thrown at him during the 2022 World Cup. Ronaldo will be hoping for a much more influential role in his 11th major tournament than at his 10th, where he was benched by former manager Fernando Santos for the knockout stages.
Any questions about the strength of competition of the Saudi Pro League is not something new manager Roberto Martinez is interested in. Martinez restored Ronaldo into his starting line-up during the Euro 2024 qualifying campaign and the striker delivered 10 goals.
“Cristiano? It’s better to talk about the data,” Martinez said, listing the statistics. “That shows his continuity and physical ability to always be fit, as well as the quality he has in front of goal, which we really like and need.”
The five-time Ballon d’Or winner holds the record for most international appearances (206) and he will have the chance to improve that and his incredible goal tally of 128.
He is a goalscoring machine. The powerful strikes, instinctive tap-ins, aerial ability and free-kick prowess make him one of football’s greatest goalscorers. While other areas of his game have diminished, the eye for goal remains.
He is already the tournament’s leading all-time goalscorer on 14 and he will be keen to add to that in Germany.

Diogo Costa
Diogo Costa wears the No 99 for Porto, a shirt number made famous by the club’s legendary goalkeeper Vitor Baia when they won the Champions League under manager Jose Mourinho in 2004. That heroic season was not enough to earn Baia a recall to the national team for Euro 2004, though, when Portugal were hosts and lost in the final to Greece.
There was never any doubt about the latest Porto No 99 being called up by Roberto Martinez. Portugal have plenty of talent in the goalkeeper position, but the 24-year-old stands out from the crowd and not just for his ability to stop penalties.
At the age of 23, he was first choice ahead of Rui Patricio for the 2022 World Cup in Qatar. When he started the opening game against Ghana, he became the youngest Portuguese goalkeeper to play at a major tournament. A change of manager from Fernando Santos to Martinez has had no impact on his place in the team.
Part of that trust is due to his excellent distribution. He confidently finds his team-mates by playing passes all over the pitch. We know how much of a high priority it is for goalkeepers to be able to use their feet and Costa is a master of this.
Pedro Pereira is a goalkeeping coach who worked with Costa in Porto’s youth system and B team between 2011 and 2021. He describes Costa as “a very complete goalkeeper”.
“Diogo can make match-winning saves, he’s really strong under the high ball and can play under pressure,” Pereira told The Athletic last summer. “He is also very comfortable with the ball at his feet. That is one of his strengths. He strikes the ball with power and precision, so he can play to any part of the pitch.”
With the wealth of attacking talent at Portugal’s disposal, Costa’s range-finding could help them punish teams in Germany.

Joao Neves
There are only three certainties in life; death, taxes and Benfica unearthing another gem from their academy.
As talent factories go, the Portuguese side are hard to beat. The list of players they have developed and sold for huge profit is forever growing. Many rise through the ranks of the academy from a young age, such as Bernardo Silva or Ruben Dias, while some, such as Enzo Fernandez, are signed for cheap and sold for an astronomical fee.
The latest diamond they are busy polishing is 19-year-old midfielder Joao Neves.
At Benfica since the age of 12, he was only beginning to make a name for himself at senior level this time last year after breaking into the first team shortly before Fernandez’s big-money move to Chelsea. The Argentina international’s exit paved the way for Neves to become a regular starter and he has not looked back.
His emergence has been expected. Handed his first professional contract in 2020, Neves played a key role in the club’s 2021-22 UEFA Youth League title. He has now clocked up 75 appearances for Benfica and earned his first international cap in October.
He can control games with his high-volume passing and ball retention. There is an ambitious streak to his play, both through passing — where he averaged 6.7 progressive passes and 6.9 passes into the final third per 90 minutes — and ball carrying, with his 1.6 successful take-ons ranking in the top sixth percentile of midfielders in the Primeira Liga.
But really, he can do everything. Neves defines all-action on and off the ball, as the graphic below demonstrates. Not only did no player in the Portuguese Primeira Liga average more than his 80.7 passes per 90, but no player made more ball recoveries than his 8.2 per 90.
Technical quality on the ball turns into tenacity off it, with his high energy matching his reading of the game to recover possession at an impressive rate through anticipated interceptions and well-timed tackles. He relishes a physical battle and despite his height (5ft 9in; 175cm), he is strong in the air.
It is no surprise he is being linked with a move away and Benfica have to be mindful of financial fair play rules, so may entertain the idea of selling him. Reports of Manchester United’s interest have been the strongest and the €120million (£102m; $130m) release clause may tempt clubs this summer. There is no doubt he is capable of playing at the very highest level.
If he follows in the footsteps of his former team-mate Fernandez and excels at a major international tournament, just as Fernandez did in Qatar, then one of the elite clubs may be unable to resist a move for this future superstar.

Rafael Leao
Rafael Leao is more than your regular footballer.
When he is not making defenders dance to his tune on the pitch, he spends time in the recording studio he installed in his home making his own.
Rap has been an influence for Leao from an early age but his passion developed into something more during COVID-19 lockdown as a way to pass the time. Leao, performing as alter ego Way 45, has recorded two rap albums, and as a self-proclaimed shy person, it allows him to express himself.
If he had to choose between the two, football would always win. Born in Almada, just outside Lisbon, the 25-year-old got his breakthrough at Sporting CP, joining aged nine and progressing through the ranks to make his debut in October 2017, scoring in the Taca de Portugal third round.
His combination of height, physicality, pace and technical quality caught the eye. Lille brought him to France in 2018 after Leao terminated his contract with Sporting following an incident which involved a group of supporters invading the Sporting training ground.
A season later he moved to Italy, joining AC Milan. He has been on an upwards trajectory ever since. Few have captured the hearts of the Milan supporters like the left-winger. He was instrumental in their first Scudetto in 11 years, earning the Serie A MVP. In his last three seasons he has hit double figures for goals and assists.
As the map below shows, Leao is a relentless dribbler down the left-flank, one of only four players to attempt over 100 take-ons across the last two Champions League campaigns. His quick feet and forward momentum help him break into dangerous areas too, as the player with the most carries into the penalty area (84) in Serie A last season.
His limitless potential gives him the ability to produce magic at any moment. He is a menace in transition, gliding past opponents and away from them via a burst of acceleration or quick change of direction.
Leao’s influence at international level is growing too. His impressive cameos in the 2022 World Cup offered a glimpse at what is to come and ahead of the upcoming tournament he has established himself as a key part of Portugal’s attack.
The attacker looks set to remain in Italy for the foreseeable future after he signed a new five-year deal last year. For any top European clubs that may want to prise him away, a reported release clause of €175million makes that difficult.

Hakan Calhanoglu
“Right now he’s the best midfielder in Italy. Maybe even the world,” the Turkey coach Vincenzo Montella said. As a claim it has been derided by those who don’t watch Hakan Calhanoglu every week. “I feel underestimated,” Calhanoglu revealed. Because if more people paid attention, they’d realise it isn’t hyperbole.
“A few months ago I said I was one of the best registi (deep-lying playmakers) and no one believed me. But I always believe in myself. I know my qualities and I’m not afraid of anyone.” He ranks the position as follows: “5) Enzo Fernandez, 4) Joshua Kimmich, 3) Toni Kroos, 2) Rodri, 1)…” Calhanoglu’s No 1.
Looking at his passing “solar system” below shows just how much of a central hub Calhanoglu has been for Inter. Whether it is a short pass to a midfield team-mate or a diagonal ping to each of Inter’s respective wing-backs, a lot of what I Nerazzurri do is likely to go through their Turkish maestro.
His reinvention from No 10 to No 6 has been one of the great tactical stories of recent seasons in European football. The 30-year-old moved from rivals AC Milan to replace Christian Eriksen, whose need for an implantable cardioverter defibrillator after suffering a cardiac arrest at Euro 2021 rendered his contract in Italy null and void.
“I called (Inter’s executives Beppe) Marotta and (Pier) Ausilio the same night (as Eriksen’s collapse) and said: ‘I’ve read Calhanoglu isn’t going to stay at Milan, he’s leaving’ and they told me they’d already contacted him,” Inter coach Simone Inzaghi revealed. “We signed him to play as a free eight and then things happened in the year that made me opt to try him there in a few training sessions.”
The things Inzaghi alludes to were the injuries to Marcelo Brozovic who was out for far longer than Inter expected. His understudy Kristjan Asllani, another entry in the Radar, wasn’t ready to step-in. “Hakan’s showings in training were persuasive. The big test, however, were the games and he just got better and better.”
By accident rather than design, Calhanoglu is grateful to Inzaghi for making his dream come true. He always wanted to play the role.
“It’s no coincidence Pirlo was my idol. I’ve made my game more well rounded particularly from a defensive point of view. Now I relish the physical battle. I might be further from goal and get to shoot less,” a shame for someone as good from distance as him, “but I get to control games, dictate the tempo and help my team-mates from the back. A goal sooner or later comes along, like the one at San Siro against Barcelona.”
Or the other 16 he has scored for club and country this season.

Kenan Yildiz
Arguably the breakout star of this season’s Serie A, Yildiz began to emerge just when Juventus’ title challenge was beginning to roll. The young Turk promised to be an unforeseen differentiator upon graduating from the club’s Next Gen team.
After cutting his hair on Max Allegri’s recommendation — “he touches it 100 times” — the teenager fleetingly gave Juventus the off-the-cuff unpredictability a creatively moribund team desperately needed.
For a time he even took Federico Chiesa’s place in the side and seemed to dovetail better with Dusan Vlahovic than the Italian winger. One of the reasons for that is his close control in tight spaces. As Turkey’s Italian coach Vincenzo Montella says: “Technically his first touch is among the best I’ve ever seen.”
Montella threw him in at the deep end in a friendly against Germany last November. He was not made to regret it. Yildiz scored in a memorable 3-2 win. “I wanted to test him in front of 70,000 fans and he responded to it like a great player.”
In Italy the hype machine cranked up after he became the youngest player to find the back of the net for Juventus since Kingsley Coman and Moise Kean. It then went into overdrive after the 19-year-old skipped past one player and then another to score a breathtaking goal from the left flank in Frosinone.
“He is the guy who has given me the most difficulties (in training),” his Juventus teammate Tarik Muharemovic told The Athletic, “because he is a special dribbler. He goes low with his knees. You have to be calm, watch the ball.”
As you can see below, Yildiz’s dribbling marries up high quantity with high quality. Only four Serie A forwards boast a higher take-on success rate than the 19-year-old’s 58 per cent.
Allegri tried to manage expectations around Yildiz and the form of the free transfer from Bayern Munich has taken a dip towards the end of the season. But he is a special talent.
“Kenan is a very good footballer, but in addition to that he is also intelligent,” Allegri, who has now left Juventus, said. “He has a great career ahead of him, all the champions I have coached were intelligent and he is intelligent too, but he will only be able to say that he has had a great career after staying seven to eight years at this level.”
